title: Positive and negative sets
summary: In measure theory, given a measurable space ( X , Σ ) {\displaystyle (X,\Sigma )} and a signed measure μ {\displaystyle \mu } on it, a set A ∈ Σ {\displaystyle A\in \Sigma } is called a .mw-parser-output .vanchor>:target~.vanchor-text{background-color:#b1d2ff}positive set for μ {\displaystyle \mu } if every Σ {\displaystyle \Sigma } -measurable subset of A {\displaystyle A} has nonnegative measure; that is, for every E ⊆ A {\displaystyle E\subseteq A} that satisfies E ∈ Σ , {\displaystyle E\in \Sigma ,} μ ( E ) ≥ 0 {\displaystyle \mu (E)\geq 0} holds.
